Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas who possess ten kinds of dharmas can perfectly accomplish a single meal.
What are the ten?
First, when accomplishing a meal, one's nature is not greedy;
Second, when accomplishing a meal, one's nature is free from attachment;
Third, when obtaining a meal, one is always content;
Fourth, one always eats at the proper time and does not eat at improper times;
Fifth, if it is for profit, one should not eat at all;
Sixth, if one obtains delicious food, one should not eat it;ğŸ”½Seventh, when seeing others eat, one should not give rise to anger;
Eighth, when seeing others eat, one should not be stingy or jealous;
Ninth, one always eats a single meal until the end of one's life;
Tenth, when eating, one should give rise to the thought of it as medicine.
Good man!
These are the ten dharmas that accomplish the merit of the wonderful practice of one meal.
Furthermore, good man!
If a bodhisattva possesses ten kinds of dharmas, he can perfect the dharma of living in an araá¹‡ya.
What are the ten?

First, accomplishing the practice of pure conduct for a long time; second, accomplishing pure precepts; third, accomplishing the undistracted faculties; fourth, accomplishing the constant delight in hearing much [of the Dharma]; fifth, accomplishing the power in all places; sixth, accomplishing the abandonment of the grasping of self; seventh, accomplishing the non-attachment to the body; eighth, accomplishing the constant delight in seclusion; ninth, accomplishing the presence of the true Dharma; tenth, accomplishing the delight in solitary places.
Good man!
How does a bodhisattva accomplish the practice of pure conduct for a long time, up to accomplishing the delight in solitude?
Good man!
In this way, the bodhisattva, having gone forth, in the teachings of the TathÄgata, is endowed with the three wheels, and the seal of precepts is pure;
Among the precepts, he attains skillful means, and without relying on the teachings of others, he is able to understand by himself.
Namely:ğŸ”½Skillful in the meaning, he is able to practice;
Skillful in the text, he is able to uphold it without forgetting;
Skillful in following the path of liberation;
Skillful in repenting and removing the five kinds of offenses;
Wherever he goes, he avoids the objects of transgression;
He is always afraid of evil people, and does not conceal even minor offenses;

He is able to fully understand the precepts, whether they are transgressions or not, and knows the length of time of such karmic actions, falling into the three evil destinies, and being reborn in the human and heavenly realms;
In this way, the bodhisattva skillfully controls the six sense faculties, keeping them from agitation and confusion. By this skillful means, he abides in the araá¹‡ya.
Dwelling in a place free from harm and difficulty, not closely associating with the dwelling places of worldly people;
Not far from cities and towns, making it easy to beg for food, with abundant medicinal herbs and pure springs;
Far from vicious animals, in a secluded and quiet place;
Relying on such a place to dwell.
With regard to what one is studying and reciting, one should be diligent;

When reciting, regulate one's breathing, and let the voice be neither too loud nor too low. The mind should not be externally distracted, but focused and mindful, contemplating the words and their meaning, free from dullness and agitation, in harmony with tranquility and insight.

If one sees ministers, brahmins, and others come to one's place, one should give rise to a respectful mind towards those who come, greet them with a smile, invite them to sit down, observe their faculties, and expound the true Dharma to them, causing them all to rejoice, believe, and practice.
If one sees the king, one should welcome him well, skillfully comply with his intentions, and say such words as:
May the great king please sit on this seat.
When the king is seated, request what he desires and provide everything.
If the king has no faith or joy, he should praise the king's virtues with good words:
I observe that the great king has attained great benefits.
Now in the king's realm, the fields of blessings of all Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as who uphold the precepts and are learned in the scriptures reside here.
By the king's power, all thieves and robbers do not come to disturb.
Due to the king's virtuous influence, all evil beasts are all driven away.

When the king hears these words, he will be overjoyed, his faculties will be subdued, his mind will be tranquil, and he will be a suitable vessel for the Dharma. The bodhisattva achieves such extensive learning and the power to be in all places, and is able to cultivate the correct practices;

Moreover, good man!
Bodhisattvas who possess ten kinds of dharmas are able to sit under trees.
What are the ten?

First, not too close to villages or towns; second, not relying on cities too far away; third, not relying on places with thorns; fourth, not relying on places with many poisonous plants; fifth, not relying on trees without branches and leaves; sixth, not relying on places with many monkeys; seventh, not relying on places where many birds gather; eighth, not relying on places where evil beasts dwell; ninth, not relying on places near enemies and thieves; tenth, not relying on places where illegal and evil practices are carried out;
one should not rely on such places.
If one can bring peace and joy to body and mind and cultivate wholesome practices, then one should abide there.
Good man!
These are the ten dharmas that the bodhisattva fully possesses, perfectly accomplishing the wonderful practice of sitting under a tree.
Furthermore, good man!
The bodhisattva, with ten dharmas, then attains perfection in sitting in the open air.
What are the ten?

First, following cold, heat, and rain, not choosing warmth or coolness; second, not relying on walls; third, not relying on trees; fourth, not relying on grass piles; fifth, not relying on dangerous places; sixth, not covering in the cold; seventh, not covering in the rain; eighth, not covering in the heat; ninth, not covering in the wind; tenth, if one has illness and suffering, one may dwell in a house.
Bodhisattvas should think like this:

'If in the open air, right mindfulness is present, and according to one's practice, afflictions are quickly eliminated, in accordance with the Buddha's teaching of the merits of dhÅ«ta, I should diligently seek and attain perfection.'
Even if dwelling in a house, one should not give rise to attachment, nor say this is good and that is bad. One should think like this:
'I dwell in the monastery, benefiting all sentient beings who cultivate merit.
Sitting in the open air cannot bring great benefit;
Moreover, sitting in the open can only benefit oneself, not others.
' Although that bodhisattva dwells in a dwelling, day and night he always thinks of sitting in the open.
Good man!
These are the ten dharmas that a bodhisattva fully possesses, perfectly accomplishing the wonderful practice and merit of sitting in the open.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas who possess ten kinds of dharmas are able to accomplish dwelling in a charnel ground.
What are the ten?

First, the thought of disgust with the world; second, the thought of the appearance of death; third, the thought of death before decay; fourth, the thought of the appearance of bluish-black [corpse]; fifth, the thought of the appearance of bloating; sixth, the thought of pus flowing and decay; seventh, the thought of being eaten by birds and beasts; eighth, the thought of being burned by fire and half-burned; ninth, the thought of the separation of limbs and joints; tenth, the thought of the appearance of skeletons.
Good man!

If bodhisattvas dwell in charnel grounds, they should always abide in a mind of loving-kindness and a mind of benefiting all beings, uphold pure precepts, guard their dignified conduct, keep their bodies clean, and should not eat meat.
Why is it so?
Dwelling in a cold forest, one should prevent two faults:
First, to avoid being criticized by non-Buddhists; second, to avoid non-humans taking advantage of them.

If those bodhisattvas enter the monastery, they should first pay homage to the Buddha's stÅ«pas and images, and pay homage to the upper, middle, and lower seats as appropriate;

This is called the bodhisattva perfecting ten dharmas, fully accomplishing the merit and virtue of dwelling in the charnel ground.
Furthermore, good sons!
If the bodhisattva perfects ten kinds of dharmas, he will be able to fully accomplish constant sitting.
What are the ten?

First, not for one's own physical fatigue; second, not for the mental heat and distress; third, not for laziness and sleep; fourth, not for standing for a long time and being uneasy; fifth, for fulfilling the aggregate of dharmas of enlightenment; sixth, for cultivating one-pointedness of mind; seventh, for seeking the present manifestation of the right path; eighth, for wishing to sit in the bodhi-manda; ninth, for wishing to benefit sentient beings; tenth, for wishing to eliminate afflictions.
Good sons!
These are the ten dharmas.
Furthermore, good sons!
If bodhisattvas have ten kinds of dharmas, they will attain perfect accomplishment in following sitting.
What are the ten?

First, following whatever seat one encounters, the mind is not attached; second, following the old spread seat, one does not set it up oneself; third, one also does not instruct others to set up a bed or seat; fourth, one does not create conditions for various bedding; fifth, encountering grass, leaves, etc., one sits according to the time; sixth, places with many poisonous insects should be avoided; seventh, when wanting to lie down, one places the right side on the ground; eighth, the mind is not negligent, thinking of getting up at the right time; ninth, one focuses the mind on the bright, sleeping in accordance with the Dharma; tenth, in order to cultivate practice, one makes the body peaceful and happy.
Good sons!
These are the ten dharmas that the bodhisattva possesses, accomplishing the merit and virtue of the wonderful practice of sitting wherever he is.
Good man!

Reflecting on his past lives, having gone through many births and deaths without cultivating reverence, he immediately gave rise to the intention to deeply reproach himself and diligently practice with effort.

Again, reflecting on his past lives, following worldly ways and committing evil deeds, he immediately gave rise to the intention:

To make his mind vast and extend to all sentient beings.

To practice the Buddha's teachings and nurture his faculties.
He also recalled his past lives, giving rise to wrong thoughts and inverted associations, and immediately made up his mind:
To give rise to the mind of right views and make bodhisattva vows.
He also recalled his past lives, laboring day and night to do evil things, and immediately made up his mind:
To give rise to great diligence and accomplish the Buddha's teachings.
He also recalled his past lives, taking rebirth in the five destinies, neither benefiting himself nor others, and immediately made up his mind:

To use his body to benefit sentient beings and accomplish the Buddha's teachings, to give rise to all sentient beings' wholesome roots, to serve all good and wise advisors, and to always be in accord with the mind of right vows;

He further contemplated this body, from beginningless time, always the root of all the sufferings of birth, old age, sickness, death, love, and separation.
